items.content_html:
Just a passing drum thought. I was just practicing and found I couldn't change from a snare fill to the ride in time. Eventually I figured out I had to hit twice with one hand instead of alternating hands on the snare. By hitting twice I effectively swapped hands for the final hit which freed up the right hand to reach the snare in time.

I think there's probably a general principle here that I need to internalize: hit twice with the hand you need to free up. Hopefully I can try it out and internalize that.

items.content_html:
I was on a bit of a roll with my home recording. But a few things have lead to that coming to a hard and sudden stop.

GarageBand -> Reaper

I worked on a few songs where I was pretty happy with the performance but not the mix. I went on a deep dive on mixing/mastering and it seemed some of the most rudimentary techniques were hard to impossible in GarageBand. I didn't really want to jump to a real DAW too soon as I just wanted to make music, but at the same time I didn't want to over invest in the wrong tools.

I also didn't see myself jumping into a very expensive tool chain, I couldn't justify that to myself, I get why music software is expensive, and I think its actually a good thing for software to be expensive, in almost all other sectors there's a serious case of deflation which leads to unsustainable business models.

But I can't blow thousands of dollars on software.

Reaper seemed like an initial compromise to get access to the powerful features of professional DAWs without the exorbitant price tag.

But after watching a lot of videos, particularly from Adam Steele I think it isn't even a compromise, it may actually be superior to more mainstream DAWs in many ways.

But I'm a fish out of water, I have no idea what I am doing, so its slowed me down.

Mac -> Windows

My M1 Macbook Air has had numerous issues in the year I've had it. Most of these issues could be subsided with a little time and effort. But recently I hit too issues that made me jump back to a Surface.

First thing was, I installed a bunch of VST instruments, and ever since then, GarageBand will randomly crash without warning. It seems this is common problem, and after following the recommended solutions and even after installing all plugins - the crashing continued.

I started migrating files off the Mac in preparation to reinstall the OS, with the intent to stay with the Mac as my main machine. Then out of nowhere the Arrow Key flew off the keyboard. I watched some videos on how to re-attach it, but then discovered part of the plastic mechanism had snapped.

I had a lot of deadlines for software projects, I needed a capable machine, so I bought a Surface (my 5th surface?). My plan was to use the Surface for work and repair the Mac for music production. But I knew Reaper worked on Windows, tried it out, and it worked perfectly so now I plan on just selling the Mac and doing everything on the one machine.

I have to say, it was a joy to be back on windows again. I had multi-monitor support again (something M1 Macbook Air's can't do!). I could play fairly recent games. I had a touch screen again, which is very useful for web/app development. I don't think I'll be back on a Mac for a long time. Windows has lots of issues, but if you know what you are doing you can curate a nice experience on the OS, its very hackable. But I found the opposite with Mac OSX.

Reaper -> Midi Instruments

GarageBand comes with a huge amount of Midi Instruments which is so great for quickly trying out different ideas - Reaper does not. So trying to build up a nice / cheap midi library has been a time sink.

Reaper -> Midi Drums

GarageBand's Midi Mapping works so well on my little Alesis CompactKit and on my Arturia MiniLab. Both instruments work on Reaper but the default Midi Mappings were a bit off, which means I need to play around with it and come up with some nice presets so I can do finger drumming and real drumming on the kit without too much friction.

Windows for Music Production

I was under the impression no-one does this. But after a bit of youtube research, it seems it is less rare than I thought. I was also pleasantly surprised that my evo4 worked out of the box with Repear. I remembered years ago trying to do the most basic recording on Windows and it being a nightmare, but so far every piece of software I've looked at has had a Windows alternative, and the trials have all worked without a hitch (and without any crashes!).

So we'll see how this goes. If there is a compelling reason to use a particular OS I'll make the switch, but I am as surprised as anyone to be back on Windows for music production, I thought that was basically impossible.

items.content_html:
Recently been playing Fallen Order. I'm so impressed by it but the key thing that stands out to me is how the level design carefully plays with linearity.

Linearity

Linearity is when you force the player to only go down one path for progression. Often blocking them with various challenges along the way to guarantee they experience exactly what we expect them to experience.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GTYa9kX-K3M

It lets the game designers "know" that you understand a mechanic or rule. Which allows them to make assumptions which in-turn make the levels more interesting.

You need to teach the player how to play. You need to make sure they understand every mechanic of the game. So every level in the first chapter needs to have some example forcing the player to do something in order to beat the level that they will need further in the game.

Linearity also aids communication between game and player. If a level is linear, and you can't continue without solving some problem, its very clear you've reached a puzzle. Its hard to have puzzles in non-linear games without somehow introducing linearity.

These puzzles also let the player experience the joy of figuring out something without aid, while also knowing the problem they are being tasked to solve is solvable and important.

Everybody in the world will see a problem and want to solve it. If you see a level where it is just a wall, and you don't realise you can keep jumping up the wall - you're going to try it right away. And once you try it yourself you've taught yourself and not only do you feel smart (you've figured out something yourself) you also now for sure know how to do that from then on in the game.

Even open world games have linearity in the form of gates. In Minecraft, you are gated by not having specific minerals or materials needed to craft items. These crafted items in turn allow you to reach areas and access materials thatwere previously not possible to obtain. Even though you can physically walk anywhere in Minecraft, you are still on a linear path of progression that was designed (unless if you are playing creative mode).

In GTA you often can't drive over a bridge, because there's a mysterious road closure. You also may find it difficult to access certain vehicles which allow you to access areas.

Games like Braid or the Witness have linear progression in a very zen like way. You always had the ability you just lacked the required knowledge.

The problem is, for adventure games, the methodology of linearity is often quite clumsy. The player notices what the game is doing, and finds the justification for it unconvincing. It can feel like you are just grinding until you get to access the "real" game.

Red Key

Comparing Fallen Order to say Force Unleashed, the level design is completely different. In Force Unleashed you are pretty much on rails from set piece to set piece. Linearity is important to create a sense of progression, but it can also feel like you are being dragged by the heels to the next QTE. It doesn't feel like you are exploring a real place.

Going back further to Jedi Outcast, we had large sprawling levels that loop around on themselves, but in Outcast those mazes feel just as artificial. Once you kill the troopers, the halls are empty, and it is easy to forget what the hell you were doing as all the various hallways bleed together. Often you revisit the same space to unlock a new area via a "key". This tradition carries us back to Dark Forces in the 90s.

Fallen Order is interesting because we don't have any keys. Areas are inaccessible because reaching a certain ledge, or breaking through a particular wall requires a power that the player is yet to learn. The difference is subtle but there's a lot of great qualities to this approach.

For one, it creates anticipation. When you haven't yet found the red key, you don't dream of the day when you'll finally have the red key, and how exciting and thrilling it will be to wield that key. The moment you collect the key, you immediately dispose of it by unlocking a door. Collecting keys isn't that different to fetch quests in World of Warcraft. It is a way of stretching out the games content by ensuring you can't visit and do everything all at once.

In contrast to the red key: a new force power changes how you interact with every other system in that world. It makes the system more complex, more interesting. While it is a gate, it is not fungible with other gates, it is a new mechanical ingredient every time. That respects the player a little more than "you need {color} key to pass this door". Ironically too, preventing you from accessing areas without a specific power actually adds value to that power in the players mind. It creates additional demand.

Shortcuts

Fallen Order also has this idea of "shortcuts". When you do return somewhere you've already visited it is generally not to proceed to some previously unlocked door (as in Outcast), it is to make repeat visits to the same worlds less arduous. As you explore a world, you increasingly find the levels are a network of secret tunnels. It makes it simple to get back to any place in the world without having to perform the same feats of strength over and over.

This makes it possible to complete a linear challenge (say exploring an underground temple, or navigating an icy cavern) and then return back to your ship and go to a different planet. As you complete parts of the world, that part of the world becomes more open and non-linear and less game-like.

Rest

Throughout the map there are checkpoints, but you have to manually opt in to them. These checkpoints are little circles on the ground where you can meditate, upgrade your force powers and "rest".

The "rest" mechanic allows you to replenish your health and stim packs but at the same time re-spawns all enemies. That second part is interesting on a few levels. The first is the implicit encouragement not to take the safe path, to continue on without healing, lest you face the same enemies you've already beaten.

Ironically this makes a game feel less like a grind. When you can safely heal with no consequences, there is no reason not to do so. A player will usually pick the optimal path even if it isn't as fun. So as a designer you have to figure out ways to either make the optimal path the most fun, or penalize the optimal path in some way to encourage the player to actually participate in the challenge. And the penalizing can so often feel unfair or arbitrary. I think this trade-off strikes the right balance.

Secondly, it means our levels are rarely empty. They feel alive, like real places. Usually you have long dispatched all the enemies and simply walk lonely hallways trying to figure out how to get pass some arbitrary gate. At least in Fallen Order, the animals and the guards are continually reborn, and because of the aforementioned trade-off, that feels fair. Or the level is empty, but you are likely low on health so there is an element of peril which keeps things interesting.

Through shortcuts, rest, and ability based gating, Fallen Order manages to change the perceived shape of its levels as you play. And therefore the genre shifts between linear on rails adventure to open world brawler/rpg. But not just once, continually. They manage to pull this off without it feeling like an experimental porridge. They get to have the epic cinematic Star Wars set pieces we expect, without the feeling you are on a guided DisneyLand tour.

items.content_html:
I finished Cloudpunk and it was great.

More thoughts below the fold.

The voice acting was excellent and the characters and their relationships felt real, especially the core cast. I also liked the way they paced the missions so that you'd immediately get a call when you got back into your vehicle but not when you're roaming around the city on foot.

Sometimes the political commentary of Cloudpunk is a bit overwrought. It's not that the commentary is bad (or even the politics), its just a little didactic and saccharine. The way they draw the connection that in this civilisation robots are the new black people or trans people in this new civilisation... it's fine, but it feels like it isn't contributing anything new and instead is delving into political territory so it can have a bit of emotional depth and complexity that it would otherwise not have.

If you are going to have some political commentary take a bit more of a chance and make a statement instead of just going "isn't this thing like this other thing ... huh"

The only reason this frustrated me was how close they came to make a point and then not doing so.

I found this thread on steam's forums from a trans person commenting on the allegory which I thought was interesting (link)

When the political commentary focused on capitalism, I think the one interesting idea was the debt corps. The idea that in the future we may be brought back to life from the dead to work off our debts. Unmistakable capitalistic logic, if we had the technology, I'm sure it would happen.

Overall I very much enjoyed Cloudpunk. I read on reddit later that the Switch port was far worse than the PC version, but I still thought it was great despite the low draw distance and very occasional crashes. But that's just me, I don't care too much about graphical fidelity, and if anything the low draw distance added to the mood.

items.title: Cloudpunk
items.summary:
I finished Cloudpunk and it was great.

More thoughts below the fold.

----------------------------------------

The voice acting was excellent and the characters and their relationships felt real, especially the core cast. I also liked the way they paced the missions so that you'd immediately get a call when you got back into your vehicle but not when you're roaming around the city on foot.

Sometimes the political commentary of Cloudpunk is a bit overwrought. It's not that the commentary is bad (or even the politics), its just a little didactic and saccharine. The way they draw the connection that in this civilisation robots are the new black people or trans people in this new civilisation... it's fine, but it feels like it isn't contributing anything new and instead is delving into political territory so it can have a bit of emotional depth and complexity that it would otherwise not have.

If you are going to have some political commentary take a bit more of a chance and make a statement instead of just going "isn't this thing like this other thing ... huh"

The only reason this frustrated me was how close they came to make a point and then not doing so.

I found this thread on steam's forums from a trans person commenting on the allegory which I thought was interesting (link [https://steamcommunity.com/app/746850/discussions/0/2270321250018217133/])

When the political commentary focused on capitalism, I think the one interesting idea was the debt corps. The idea that in the future we may be brought back to life from the dead to work off our debts. Unmistakable capitalistic logic, if we had the technology, I'm sure it would happen.

Overall I very much enjoyed Cloudpunk. I read on reddit later that the Switch port was far worse than the PC version, but I still thought it was great despite the low draw distance and very occasional crashes. But that's just me, I don't care too much about graphical fidelity, and if anything the low draw distance added to the mood.
